awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Achieving Multicomponent Active Materials through Synergistic Combinatorial, Informatics-enabled Materials Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical: Affordable, low-cost flexible electronics will revolutionize how society thinks about and uses devices in applications ranging from energy storage and conversion, displays, or sensors for environmental and health monitoring. Conjugated polymers can provide the key functional component for electrical performance; however, control of the thin-film, active-layer morphology presents a key challenge. This Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) project merges knowledge from polymer design, synthesis and processing, high-throughput combinatorial materials discovery, multiscale materials simulation, and materials informatics to stimulate the discovery of new generations of flexible, stretchable and high-temperature semiconductors enabled by blends of conjugated polymers and electrically inert polymers that exhibit unprecedented and robust performance. The discoveries will enable the widespread commercialization and utilization of flexible electronics. In addition, the project will develop generalizable materials genome methods for integration of high-throughput experiment and informatics in organic electronic systems. Students participants will realize multidisciplinary benefits. They will be cross-trained and have opportunities to expand their knowledge and experience through relevant additional collaborations; and they will be encouraged to participate in broadening experiences, such as industrial internships, teaching practicums and energy policy courses, based on individual interests and career goals. The PIs will build upon existing mentoring programs for female graduate students, using ongoing monthly lunch groups as a hub to provide professional development and leadership opportunities for students, expanding its reach through additional programs, including seminar speakers and panel discussions.

Technical: Affordable, low-cost flexible electronics will revolutionize how society thinks about and uses devices in applications ranging from energy storage and conversion, displays, or sensors for environmental and health monitoring. However, satisfying the functional and economic requirements of target applications and the constraints of large-scale solution-based additive fabrication processes requires increasingly complex solution formulations. Dilution of the active semiconducting polymer in an insulating matrix is an exciting and emerging opportunity to achieve the desired functional attributes in an economically viable approach. In that regard a key challenge is control of the thin-film, active-layer morphology to achieve exceptional levels of charge transport performance that will be imperative for envisioned applications. Here, new polymer chemistry is combined with materials modeling to explore electronic properties and molecular scale interactions and dynamics in solution and blends to inform high-throughput experiments. These data will then serve as the key inputs of materials informatics approaches that will establish critical connections among composition, structure and processing. The objective is to build the materials genome that will provide knowledge to inform materials development at all stages along the structure-processing-function paradigm. The project will create a holistic foundation connecting molecular structure to polymer chain dynamics from the solution level to solidified thin-film morphology to electronic performance; and motivate the realization of ubiquitous, cost-effective and sustainable organic electronics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major goal in this project was to demonstrate an effective pipeline for non-Edisonian design of organic semiconductor (OSC) technologies, with particular focus on the mechanisms that govern the transition from the solution state to the thin film. A key hypothesis driving this project was that a tight ‘feedback loop’ among detailed experiments and simulations combined with high-throughput experiments and informatics is required to traverse the wide chemical, physical, and processing parameter spaces of these materials. The holistic approach for this project aimed to develop knowledge and models required to engineer blended polymeric semiconductors that demonstrate enhanced electrical performance in flexible devices, air stability and mechanical properties. Further, the aim was to use a minimum of expensive semiconducting polymers while simultaneously maintaining ease of processability, thereby laying a foundation for cost-effective, more sustainable, flexible devices.

This team science effort demonstrated facilitated demonstration of a gradient film deposition setup that enabled comprehensive investigation of the process-structure-property relationships in multicomponent semiconducting polymer thin film systems. The compositional landscape of polymer semiconductor/insulator blends was explored using an automated flow system for high-throughput experimentation. The collected data, combined with materials informatics/data-science techniques, allowed for high-resolution model fitting of the intricate relationship between polymer composition and device performance, surpassing one-composition-at-a-time experiments. A key aspect of the project was to design and implement an object-relational database for storing experimental records. This database aimed to address the lack of standardized reporting and the limited availability of representative experimental data in this field. A data ontology was developed to describe the parameters involved in transforming a semiconducting polymer into the active layer of a device, with a focus on capturing process history in a relational data structure using an international batch process control standard. A major activity included database design, experimental data curation, and backend tool development to create a robust, publicly accessible, repository of organic electronic devices. This database has proven to be a valuable tool for informing process-structure-property relationships in this domain, enhancing visualization, analysis, and data-driven learning to improve organic device designs.

The optical and electronic properties of the polymer semiconductors were further explored via a multiscale computational approach that included density functional theory (DFT), time-dependent DFT, and molecular dynamics simulations. The goal was to provide chemical insights into the polymers’ physical properties starting at the atomistic level for comparison to experimental results. The DFT calculations of selected systems were in good agreement with spectroscopic experiment results. The computation studies were also validated through experimental exploration of process-structure-property relationships. For instance, the influence of solution concentration on the optoelectronic properties of semiconducting polymer solutions were performed and device performance was investigated to validate the results from database analyses. A significant finding was that the thin-film properties of the polymers critically depended on the behavior of the polymer chain in the solution state.

This investigation provided full or partial support for seven Ph.D. students and one Postdoctoral researcher. The grad students and postdoc honed their leadership skills through mentoring several undergraduates, many of whom have entered graduate school to continue their education. They communicated their research in peer-reviewed publications and presentations at professional society meetings. Importantly, the students trained through this research activity were also fully engaged in outreach to K-12 students and the general public. Two of the graduate students have transitioned to industrial R&D positions, while five are in the process of completing their studies. The Postdoctoral researcher has transitioned to faculty position at a predominantly undergrad institution. All students associated with this program were engaged in multidisciplinary studies at the intersection of materials science, chemistry, physics, and chemical engineering, and were immersed in data science approaches for solving today’s complex problems. As a result, they developed the skills necessary to be effective global leaders engaged in the design, development and implementation of new advanced technologies for societal well-being.

 


Last Modified: 08/19/2024
Modified by: Chad Risko
